header.title: Calling Down The Moon and the Shades of Lilith

central_thesis: The central thesis of this work is to provide a structured ritual for practitioners to invoke and embody powerful lunar and chthonic Goddess archetypes, primarily Lilith, within a Sabbatic Circle. It aims to awaken the 'Serpent children of Cain' consciousness within participants, facilitating direct communication and manifestation of these entities and fostering a deeper connection with the 'mighty dead' and the 'Witch Queen' principle.

structure_content.chapter_title: Ritual Preparation and Setting the Space
structure_content.summary: This section details the necessary attire for the Priestess (white or black robe, Lilith/Babalon sigil) and Priest (white or black robe). It also specifies ritual tools such as the Kangling (human thigh bone trumpet) for calling shadow forms and a Kapala (human skull cap) for consuming a specific elixir. The initial step involves the 'Sabbatic casting of Circle' where participants join hands, envisioning the 'mighty dead' arising and seeking communion.

The ritual proceeds with alternating invocations. The Priestess, standing in the North, breathes in the 'air of Night' and the 'shadows of the dead', identifying it with the 'light of the Moon' and the 'Witch Queen', declaring the circle a place for the Lady's presence. Subsequently, the Priest, standing to the South of the altar, raises his arms and proclaims the participants as 'children of the Moon' and 'born of shining light of Lucifer', recognizing the Goddess within the 'eye of night' and themselves.

The Priestess then addresses the circle, emphasizing the collective will to manifest the 'Serpent children of Cain' consciousness and connect with the 'Dead'. Following this, the Priest initiates a sequence of potent invocations, raising his arms in the Egyptian supplicant position, calling upon specific ancient names: Hecate, Aradia, Isis, Davcina, and Babalon. After each invocation by the Priest, the Priestess affirms with 'IO [Deity Name]!'. The sequence culminates with the invocation of Lilith, 'Queen of Night faring Beings and Queen of the Sabbath', again affirmed by the Priestess.

After the series of invocations, the Priestess, facing the Priest and holding out her arms in the 'Goddess {Isis} position', enters a state of direct embodiment, becoming a 'vessel for the Witch Queen of the Moon'. She delivers a powerful 'charge', declaring herself the 'Night Star', 'Dark Bringer of dreams', 'Mistress to all the elements', and 'Queen of Heaven, Queen of Hell', among other epithets, proclaiming her words as law and enduring for ages. This is the core manifestation of the Goddess through the Priestess.

During or after the charge, the Priestess may perform the Kapala ritual, bringing the 'Human Skull Cap' to her mouth to drink its contents. If blood is used, she may anoint her face and chest, symbolizing 'the great awakening of consciousness'. The Priestess may speak further if inspired by the Goddess within her. Once completed, she lowers her arms, and the Priest offers thanks to the 'lovely and terrible Goddess of the Moon', acknowledging her beauty and presence from the depths.
The ritual concludes with 'The closing of the Circle.' and the affirmation 'So Mote It Be.'

key_concepts.definition: The primary invoked deity, referred to as 'Queen of Night faring Beings and Queen of the Sabbath'. She is the ultimate 'Witch Queen' whose presence is sought to be manifested through the Priestess.
Invoked as 'Seven Pointed Star of Lust and Manifestation', a figure originating from Thelemic esotericism, integrated here into a wider pantheon of chthonic feminine power.
Invoked as 'Lady of the Silver Bowl, Guardian of hidden knowledge', a chthonic goddess of witchcraft, crossroads, and magic, traditionally associated with the moon and night.
Invoked as 'Beloved daughter of the Sun and Moon', a figure from Italian stregheria (witchcraft) lore, symbolizing a lineage of witches and divine feminine knowledge.

Invoked as 'Eternal Queen of the Immortals and walker of the rays of luna', the Egyptian goddess of magic, motherhood, and healing, whose pose is specifically referenced for the Priestess during the charge.
Invoked as 'Elder form of the Succubi gifted unto dreaming man', an esoteric name likely associated with nocturnal entities, dreams, and subtle sexual currents within the Luciferian tradition.

A ritual implement, specifically a 'Human thigh bone trumpet or other instruments of bone', utilized 'to call the shadow forms on the astral plane', linking the ritual to necromantic or chthonic evocations.

A ritual implement, a 'Human Skull Cap', used for 'the drinking of a specific elixer', and optionally for anointing with blood, symbolizing the 'great awakening of consciousness' and often associated with tantric or death-positive traditions.

A specific method of ritual space consecration, distinct from traditional ceremonial magic circles, emphasizing collective energy, the presence of the 'mighty dead', and connection to 'Sabbatic witchcraft' traditions.

A specific esoteric lineage or state of being, whose 'spirits is the knowledge of the Dead and how they may arise to join us again', implying a Gnostic or Luciferian perspective on ancestry, awakening, and hidden knowledge.

The role of the Priestess during the climax of the ritual, where she serves as a physical and spiritual conduit for the invoked Goddess (the 'Witch Queen'), allowing the deity to speak and act through her physical form.

practical_system.description: This document outlines a specific group ritual system designed for the invocation and temporary embodiment of powerful lunar and chthonic Goddesses, primarily Lilith, through a Priestess. The system focuses on creating a consecrated space via a 'Sabbatic casting of Circle', systematically calling upon various deities, and culminating in the Priestess serving as a direct vessel for the 'Witch Queen'. It emphasizes direct spiritual experience, energetic manifestation, and the use of symbolic tools to awaken intrinsic 'Serpent' consciousness within the participants.
tools: White or black robes (for Priestess and Priest)
Sigil of Lilith or Babalon (worn by Priestess)
Kangling (Human thigh bone trumpet or other bone instruments)
rituals: Robing and adornment of Priestess with Lilith/Babalon sigil; Priest in robes.
Sabbatic casting of Circle by joining hands, envisioning 'mighty dead' arising.
Priestess's opening invocation from the North, declaring the circle as a place for the Lady.
Priest's counter-invocation from the South of the altar, identifying as 'children of the Moon' and 'light of Lucifer'.
Priestess's address to the circle, setting intention for manifesting 'Serpent children of Cain' consciousness.
Priest raises arms in 'Egyptian supplicant position' for successive invocations of Hecate, Aradia, Isis, Davcina, and Babalon.
Priestess, in 'pentagram position', affirms each invocation with 'IO [Deity Name]!'.
Priest's invocation of Lilith, 'Queen of Night faring Beings and Queen of the Sabbath', affirmed by Priestess.
Priestess holds arms in 'Goddess {Isis} position', becomes a vessel for the 'Witch Queen', and delivers the 'charge' (self-declaration of the Goddess).
Optional Kapala ritual: Priestess drinks elixir from the 'Human Skull Cap', possibly anointing with blood for 'awakening of consciousness'.
Priest offers thanks to the 'Goddess of the Moon' for her presence.
Closing of the Circle with 'So Mote It Be.'

relevant_quotes.text: The Priestess should be robed in white or black, a sigil of Lilith or Babalon in between her breasts. The Priest should be adorned in a white robe as well (black if desired). A Kangling (Human thigh bone trumpet or other instruments of bone) may be used to call the shadow forms on the astral plane, and a Kapala for the drinking of a specific elixer.
We are the Serpent children of Cain, and thus in our spirits is the knowledge of the Dead and how they may arise to join us again.

I am the Night Star that rises from the dark and twilight Sea, the depths of the mind. Dark Bringer of dreams, awakening of Manes. Though I am known by many of a thousand names, Yet the whole Earth doth venerate Me and lust unto me. I am Nature and the beauty of the Green Earth, but also the blackest sea. Mistress to all the elements. Sovereign of the Shadows Queen of Heaven, Queen of Hell, Queen of the dead Queen of the blessed dark immortals. The Single Manifestation of All Gods and Goddesses that Are. Hearken unto My Words and look unto Me! That I call unto thee and become a vessel for thy being, do become again unto my very body! And thus shall thy Spirit attain To the deepest Mysteries of Life and Death. And thus shall thine Inmost Divine Self be enfolded in the ecstasies of the Infinite! These things have I made Law by Will alone. Enduring for the ages of time.
Oh lovely and terrible Goddess of the Moon, Beautiful unto the living and the dead Gracious Lady, our thanks to Thee, For coming to us from the depths!

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant to contemporary Left-Hand Path and Luciferian magical practices, specifically within the Draconian current championed by Michael Ford. It offers a practical framework for direct invocation and embodiment of chthonic-lunar feminine divinities, blending elements from traditional witchcraft (Sabbatic circle), Thelema (Babalon), Egyptian esotericism (Isis), and modern dark occultism (Lilith, Davcina, Serpent children of Cain). Its significance lies in providing a working template for group ritual aimed at transgressive spiritual awakening and forging personal connections with adversarial and 'hidden' divine forces, positioning the practitioner as a 'vessel' for direct manifestation rather than mere supplicant. The use of bone instruments and a skull cup links it to older, more primal or necromantic ritual traditions, placing it firmly within a challenging and transformative magical paradigm.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists of experienced practitioners of Luciferianism, Draconian magic, and the Left-Hand Path. It is suitable for those comfortable with intense energetic work, direct invocation and potential embodiment of chthonic deities, and the use of 'darker' or transgressive symbolism (e.g., Kapala, blood anointing, 'Serpent children of Cain'). This is not an introductory text and requires a foundational understanding of occult concepts and ritual safety protocols for effective and responsible practice.
